results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film depicts a trip to Andamooka Opal Field in South Australia. Andamooka was established following the discovery of opal there in 1930, and largely consisted of scattered miners’ camps. The film includes footage of the mines, the miners, the dugouts and shacks that comprised the settlement, and close-ups of opals in display cases.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:29:00 bus ride through the South Australian outback
00:02:19:00 handpainted sign reading ‘Welcome to Andamooka Opal Field’
00:03:01:00 mine shafts
00:03:15:00 group of people examining the opal field, including a young girl in a pink pinafore
00:04:51:00 a mine shaft with pulley system
00:05:20:00 man skipping down the hill
00:05:33:00 the Andamooka Post Office
00:06:33:00 shanty structures
00:07:00:00 Aboriginal children playing
00:08:30:00 a man being hoisted out of a mine shaft
00:09:41:00 two miners chatting
00:10:11:00 close-ups of opals in display cases
00:12:26:00 sunset over the opal fields

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is entitled ‘Daddy wouldn’t buy me a Bow-Bow’ and is credited to Tibor and Merna Koller. It is staged as a narrative film, following a teenage girl, presumably the couple’s daughter, visiting a kennel to buy a puppy and bringing it home.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title card ‘Daddy wouldn’t buy me a Bow-Bow’ followed by ‘Produced by Tibor & Merna Koller 1968’
00:00:29:00 calendar indicating the date 28 November 1968
00:00:36:00 footage of a teenage girl sleeping, interspersed with footage of puppies, indicating she is dreaming
00:01:37:00 the newspaper boy arrives on a bicycle
00:02:15:00 sign ‘Victorian Animal Aid Trust’
00:02:31:00 girl patting puppies through a diamond wire fence
00:04:39:00 girl and puppy playing in the front yard of their house
00:04:51:00 giving the dog a bath in the laundry sink
00:06:00:00 having a nap in the sun together
00:06:11:00 title card ‘The End, Daddy DID buy me a Bow-Bow’

results.title: [KenRa Films Present Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 12. Car Racing] [excerpt]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This excerpt of Reel 12 of the film shows the family at a motor sport event held 1957 - 1959 Albert Park. A printed program reads ‘Second Day: 24th March 1957, Victorian Trophy Race, Organised by the Light Car Club of Australia’. The Light Car Club of Australia held motor races at Albert Park in between 1953 and 1958.

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

In this film, Ted captures a trip to Queensland and New South Wales. The film features scenes of holidaying in Queensland, touring around Surfers Paradise, Brisbane, the Sunshine Coast and Coffs Harbour, before travelling down the East Coast from Sydney to Eden and Lakes Entrance. The film includes memorable scenes such as a show of aqua ballet and water ski stunts in Surfers Paradise, dolphins in the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, historic buildings in Brisbane and fruit farms on the Sunshine Coast.

Of particular interest is Lennon’s Hotel in Broadbeach, which was one of the earliest hotels in Surfers Paradise. At the time, there were few buildings around and the hotel was surrounded by stretches of sand dunes and unsealed roads. It would become the site of the current ‘Oasis Shopping Centre’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 title ‘Queensland Gold Coast 1961’ followed by a sequence where travel brochures are tossed over the title card for hotels and destinations including Brampton Island and Surfers Paradise
00:00:23:00 looking toward Lennon’s Hotel, a very colourful, modern 1960s style roadside hotel
00:00:50:00 sign ‘Welcome to Surfers Paradise’
00:00:55:00 scenes around the pool at the hotel including women sunbaking in bikinis
00:01:32:00 sign ‘KR Darling Downs Bacon’ above a shopping plaza
00:02:37:00 the bridge to Chevron Island in Queensland
00:02:54:00 sign in dry grassland for ‘Shopping Centre Here’
00:03:24:00 handpainted sign for ‘Water Ski Revue and Aqua Ballet’ in Surfers Paradise Gardens
00:03:48:00 scenes of spectators on grassy slopes and the performers on the waterskiing show
00:04:41:00 a woman with a full head of hair ‘curlers’ which was a not uncommon look in the 1960s
00:04:51:00 a woman in costume for the aqua ballet, wearing a blue feathered tutu
00:05:04:00 various waterskiing stunts entertain the appreciative crowd
00:06:22:00 Mount Coot-Tha in Brisbane, a mountain with panoramic views over the city
00:08:14:00 traffic on a main road lined with palm trees
00:09:38:00 view of Brisbane City Hall
00:10:00:00 view of the Queensland National Art Gallery in its former premises on Gregory Terrace where it operated from 1931 to 1974
00:10:25:00 sign for the ‘Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary estd. 1927’
00:10:37:00 a koala riding on the back of a German Shepherd dog, hugging its neck
00:11:35:00 view of the grand sandstone Forgan Smith Building at the University of Queensland
00:13:26:00 exterior of the Buderim Ginger Growers Co-Op’s original ‘Merrybud’ factory, west of Mooloolaba on the Sunshine Coast
00:13:48:00 fruit farms, including strawberry fields and pineapple groves
00:17:00:00 fruit pickers and workers in the cane fields
00:20:11:00 kite surfer on the river
00:20:57:00 bougainvillea and two women in the gardens
00:22:00:00 banana plants
00:22:37:00 title card ‘Caloundra’
00:22:45:00 exterior of the Reef Hotel
00:23:34:00 large ship arriving on the coast
00:24:02:00 title card ‘Coolangatta’
00:24:05:00 exterior of the Kirra Beach Hotel
00:24:39:00 the Natureland Zoological Gardens
00:28:38:00 swimming and snorkelling with 1950s examples of oxygen tanks
00:29:37:00 exterior view of the George Gilltrap’s Auto Museum with displays of early twentieth century cars and trucks
00:30:48:00 a demonstration of a 1913 fire engine with a group of firemen dressed in uniform, watched by a crowd of onlookers
00:31:50:00 men pumping the fire hose
00:33:40:00 the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, a small aquarium
00:35:07:00 visitors feeding dolphins, leaping up to catch fish from people’s hands
00:37:29:00 sign for ‘Galapagos Island Giant Tortoise’ named Harry
00:38:47:00 sign for ‘The Sanctuary’ across a river
00:38:53:00 rosellas feeding
00:39:16:00 two women feeding rosellas from bowls, birds landing on their heads and arms
00:39:36:00 a toddler screaming as a kangaroo paws its head
00:40:32:00 the Terranora Lakes Country Club Estate with golf course and swimming pool
00:41:30:00 the Hornibrook Bridge, a heritage-listed bridge built by Manuel Hornibrook in the early 1930s crossing Bramble Bay
00:42:39:00 the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:42:52:00 Macquarie Lightstation, Vaucluse, which was Australia’s first lighthouse
00:44:27:00 focused views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, followed by views across the harbour
00:46:09:00 title card reads ‘Eden’
00:46:21:00 a campfire on the beach with a billy boiling
00:47:05:00 title card ‘Lakes Entrance’ followed by views over the estuary
00:47:51:00 fisherman pulling fish from a net on a dinghy
00:48:55:00 roadside picnic with table set up and playpen for a toddler
00:49:58:00 cooking sausages and bacon over stones
00:50:30:00 title card ‘The End’

00:48:55:00 roadside picnic with table set up and playpen for a toddler
00:49:58:00 cooking sausages and bacon over stones
00:50:30:00 title card ‘The End’
description_for_label:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

In this film, Ted captures a trip to Queensland and New South Wales. The film features scenes of holidaying in Queensland, touring around Surfers Paradise, Brisbane, the Sunshine Coast and Coffs Harbour, before travelling down the East Coast from Sydney to Eden and Lakes Entrance. The film includes memorable scenes such as a show of aqua ballet and water ski stunts in Surfers Paradise, dolphins in the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, historic buildings in Brisbane and fruit farms on the Sunshine Coast.

Of particular interest is Lennon’s Hotel in Broadbeach, which was one of the earliest hotels in Surfers Paradise. At the time, there were few buildings around and the hotel was surrounded by stretches of sand dunes and unsealed roads. It would become the site of the current ‘Oasis Shopping Centre’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 title ‘Queensland Gold Coast 1961’ followed by a sequence where travel brochures are tossed over the title card for hotels and destinations including Brampton Island and Surfers Paradise
00:00:23:00 looking toward Lennon’s Hotel, a very colourful, modern 1960s style roadside hotel
00:00:50:00 sign ‘Welcome to Surfers Paradise’
00:00:55:00 scenes around the pool at the hotel including women sunbaking in bikinis
00:01:32:00 sign ‘KR Darling Downs Bacon’ above a shopping plaza
00:02:37:00 the bridge to Chevron Island in Queensland
00:02:54:00 sign in dry grassland for ‘Shopping Centre Here’
00:03:24:00 handpainted sign for ‘Water Ski Revue and Aqua Ballet’ in Surfers Paradise Gardens
00:03:48:00 scenes of spectators on grassy slopes and the performers on the waterskiing show
00:04:41:00 a woman with a full head of hair ‘curlers’ which was a not uncommon look in the 1960s
00:04:51:00 a woman in costume for the aqua ballet, wearing a blue feathered tutu
00:05:04:00 various waterskiing stunts entertain the appreciative crowd
00:06:22:00 Mount Coot-Tha in Brisbane, a mountain with panoramic views over the city
00:08:14:00 traffic on a main road lined with palm trees
00:09:38:00 view of Brisbane City Hall
00:10:00:00 view of the Queensland National Art Gallery in its former premises on Gregory Terrace where it operated from 1931 to 1974
00:10:25:00 sign for the ‘Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary estd. 1927’
00:10:37:00 a koala riding on the back of a German Shepherd dog, hugging its neck
00:11:35:00 view of the grand sandstone Forgan Smith Building at the University of Queensland
00:13:26:00 exterior of the Buderim Ginger Growers Co-Op’s original ‘Merrybud’ factory, west of Mooloolaba on the Sunshine Coast
00:13:48:00 fruit farms, including strawberry fields and pineapple groves
00:17:00:00 fruit pickers and workers in the cane fields
00:20:11:00 kite surfer on the river
00:20:57:00 bougainvillea and two women in the gardens
00:22:00:00 banana plants
00:22:37:00 title card ‘Caloundra’
00:22:45:00 exterior of the Reef Hotel
00:23:34:00 large ship arriving on the coast
00:24:02:00 title card ‘Coolangatta’
00:24:05:00 exterior of the Kirra Beach Hotel
00:24:39:00 the Natureland Zoological Gardens
00:28:38:00 swimming and snorkelling with 1950s examples of oxygen tanks
00:29:37:00 exterior view of the George Gilltrap’s Auto Museum with displays of early twentieth century cars and trucks
00:30:48:00 a demonstration of a 1913 fire engine with a group of firemen dressed in uniform, watched by a crowd of onlookers
00:31:50:00 men pumping the fire hose
00:33:40:00 the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, a small aquarium
00:35:07:00 visitors feeding dolphins, leaping up to catch fish from people’s hands
00:37:29:00 sign for ‘Galapagos Island Giant Tortoise’ named Harry
00:38:47:00 sign for ‘The Sanctuary’ across a river
00:38:53:00 rosellas feeding
00:39:16:00 two women feeding rosellas from bowls, birds landing on their heads and arms
00:39:36:00 a toddler screaming as a kangaroo paws its head
00:40:32:00 the Terranora Lakes Country Club Estate with golf course and swimming pool
00:41:30:00 the Hornibrook Bridge, a heritage-listed bridge built by Manuel Hornibrook in the early 1930s crossing Bramble Bay
00:42:39:00 the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:42:52:00 Macquarie Lightstation, Vaucluse, which was Australia’s first lighthouse
00:44:27:00 focused views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, followed by views across the harbour
00:46:09:00 title card reads ‘Eden’
00:46:21:00 a campfire on the beach with a billy boiling
00:47:05:00 title card ‘Lakes Entrance’ followed by views over the estuary
00:47:51:00 fisherman pulling fish from a net on a dinghy
00:48:55:00 roadside picnic with table set up and playpen for a toddler
00:49:58:00 cooking sausages and bacon over stones
00:50:30:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film features a school for children with special needs. We see the children undertaking classroom activities and hear interviews with the teachers.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:09:00 children sit on the floor ready to play musical instruments followed by views of the children enjoying playing with the instruments
00:00:32:00 interview with a teacher discussing the lessons children are involved in that day
00:01:50:00 one of the teachers addresses the camera directly to discuss future plans for the school
00:02:24:00 the children take part in a shopping expedition
00:02:36:00 painting at easels
00:03:49:00 activities with the grocery items bought earlier
00:04:14:00 individual lesson in shopping for a teenager

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

In this film there are views around Ballarat and members of the Anderson and Bourke families take a trip to the snow. There are some great moments of comedy, beginning with a man and his perilous tower climb, then fun and games at a family card game, then to a pretend plane crash.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:51:00 a man climbs a tower whilst holding his camera and proceeds to take photos from the top after which he comes down and collapses with feigned exhaustion
00:02:18:00 a football field from overhead
00:02:30:00 scenes round Ballarat streets
00:03:08:00 the Buck’s Head Hotel in Ballarat
00:03:16:00 backyard scenes
00:03:20:00 family members playing cards which turns into a comedy when one man pretends to cheat
00:04:09:00 a small plane is ditched in a paddock and we see a man staggering out of the cockpit and collapsing onto the ground feigning injury

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 4 and Reel 5] [excerpts]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The collection is filmed on 16mm and 9.5mm film and the films can sometimes be a bit damaged and shaky.

This 9.5mm example is from excerpts of Reels 4 and 5, showing scenes of Jack’s family and friends enjoying their scrambler motor bikes in muddy conditions at Korweinguboora, near Ballarat, Victoria. A group of friends are then shown travelling around the Victorian countryside on motorcycles (motorbikes). Motorcycles have been filmed from a vehicle travelling alongside. The bike riders gather for the camera at the ‘Atlantic Garage’ possibly in Ballarat and then head off for a ride down a dusty country road.

results.title: [Cinesound Review: Royal Tour Concludes]
results.brief_description:
This film is a Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The newsreel shows the final leg of the 1970 Royal Tour with Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh and Princess Anne, for the bicentenary celebrations of the arrival of Captain James Cook in Australia in 1770.

The film shows the royal family arriving in Brisbane, Queensland, on the Royal Yacht Britannia, where they are greeted by crowds of people in hundreds of boats on the river. It shows the family attending various events, including a welcome at Parliament House, theatre shows and a children’s parade at Lang Park, or Brisbane Stadium.

Princess Anne visits a sheep station at Cunnamulla, Queensland, while Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip visit the mines at Mount Isa, Queensland.

The film shows bicentenary celebrations in Cooktown, Queensland, and Botany Bay, New South Wales. These celebrations include a speech by the Queen and re-enactments of Captain James Cook’s arrival in Australia in 1770, with interactions with Aboriginal Australian people.

The film continues with fireworks over Sydney Harbour; an ANZAC Day march in Canberra, Australian Capital Territory; Prince Philip playing polo with a local team; and the opening of the international terminal at Sydney Airport, from which the royal family departs.

results.title: [Around Australia with Movietone; Gt. Barrier Reef; Sporting Highlights; Skiing; 1949 Melbourne Cup]
results.brief_description:
This film is a Movietone Newsreel, a theatrical news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. This newsreel consists of five sections, covering news and events around Australia in 1949.

The first section, titled ‘Around Australia with Movietone’, photographed by J. W. Trerise shows pearl divers in Darwin, Northern Territory. The film takes place on a Japanese lugger, featuring Japanese divers and Peter Nakashiba, an interpreter and advisor to the Japanese in Darwin. It shows the protective diving suits and apparatus worn by pearl divers.

The second section is titled ‘Gt Barrier Reef’ and shows people fishing from trawlers on the Great Barrier Reef. The narrator describes the fishing as a popular sport and names the type of fish, including Spanish mackerel.

In the third section, ‘Sporting Highlights’, we see a horse rodeo in Warwick, Queensland, with commentary by Jack Davey, a popular radio entertainer who narrated Movietone News reels from the 1930s to 1950s.

The fourth section is titled ‘Skiing’, and takes place at Mount Kosciuszko, showing the ski fields and resort as a popular tourist destination. It includes footage of George Day, the manager of the Chalet at Charlotte Pass and a renowned Australian skier.

The final section, titled ‘1949 Melbourne Cup’, shows the popular horse racing event at Flemington Race Course, Melbourne, which in 1949 was won by Foxzami.
